body.p:
Dear Sir I have learned with suprise and regret that Mr Franklin Gorin of Louisville has been indicted for malicious shooting. I have known Mr Gorin all my life, and I think I can say with the utmost confidence that he is not the character of man to be guilty of such an offence Mr Gorin is not the man to bear malice, I know him to be an impulsius man, but of high strung and manly and noble sentiments and sympathies such indeed as adorn human nature. I would most respectfully suggest that his pardon would not militate against the publick interests of the county, but, upon the contrary would be but such an exercise of
of clemency and mercy as might be well extended to an old man who has acted a faithful post for his country and the best interestes of society. If Mr Gorin has at any time deviated from the character I have given him I feel assured that such deviations have been the result of excitement rather than malice and malevolence

I remain very truly &c
John W Ritter
P S. I feel assured that every Union man in this portion of the state would be pleased to know that Mr Gorin was pardoned
